text: Yahweh called Moses and spoke to him from the tent of meeting. He said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If any of you bring a sacrifice to Yahweh, you must offer an animal from your cattle, sheep, or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you bring a burnt offering from your cattle, you must offer a male that has no defects. Offer it at the entrance to the tent of meeting so that Yahweh will accept you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place your hand on the animal’s head. The burnt offering will be accepted to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then slaughter the bull in Yahweh’s presence. Aaron’s sons, the priests, will offer the blood. They will throw it against all sides of the altar that is at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Skin the burnt offering, and cut it into pieces.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the sons of the priest Aaron will start a fire on the altar and lay the wood on the fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s sons, the priests, will also lay the pieces, the head, and the fat on top of the wood burning on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wash the internal organs and legs. Then the priest will burn all of it on the altar. It is a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your offering is a sheep or goat, you must bring a male that has no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Slaughter it in Yahweh’s presence on the north side of the altar. Aaron’s sons, the priests, will throw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then cut it into pieces. The priest will lay the head and the fat on the wood burning on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wash the internal organs and legs. Then the priest will burn all of it on the altar. It is a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your offering to Yahweh is a bird, you must sacrifice a mourning dove or pigeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must bring it to the altar. He will break its neck and burn the bird on the altar. First, he will drain the blood against the side of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove the gizzard with its filth and throw it on the east side of the altar on the place for the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then pull on the bird’s wings to tear the bird open, but don’t pull the wings off. Then the priest will lay the bird on the wood burning on the altar. It is a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Now, if any of you bring a grain offering to Yahweh, your offering must be flour. Pour olive oil on it, and put incense on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring it to Aaron’s sons, the priests. Take from this a handful of flour with olive oil, and all the incense. The priest will burn it on the altar as a reminder. It is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the grain offering will belong to Aaron and his sons. It is very holy, set apart from Yahweh’s offering by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you bring a grain offering which has been baked in an oven, it must be rings of unleavened bread made of flour mixed with olive oil or wafers of unleavened bread brushed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your grain offering is prepared in a frying pan, it, too, will be unleavened bread made of flour mixed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: Break it into pieces and pour olive oil over it. It is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your grain offering is prepared in a skillet, it will be made of flour with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring Yahweh the grain offering prepared in any of these ways. Offer it to the priest who will bring it to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will remove part of the grain offering and burn it as a reminder on the altar. It is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the grain offering belongs to Aaron and his sons. It is very holy, set apart from Yahweh’s offering by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every grain offering that you bring to Yahweh must be prepared without yeast. Never burn yeast or honey as an offering to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may bring them to Yahweh as offerings of your first products. But they must never be placed on the altar to make a soothing aroma.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also put salt on each of your grain offerings. The salt of Elohim’s promise must never be left out of your grain offerings. Put salt on all your offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you bring a grain offering to Yahweh from the first grain you harvest, roast the cracked grain over fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put olive oil on it, and place incense on it. It is a grain offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will burn the flour, olive oil, and all the incense as a reminder. It is an offering by fire to Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “If your sacrifice is a fellowship offering of cattle in Yahweh’s presence, it must be a male or female animal that has no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place your hand on the animal’s head. Then slaughter it at the entrance to the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons, the priests, will throw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: From your offering remove the fat that covers the internal organs
speaker: Narrator

text: and the two kidneys with the fat on them and offer them by fire to Yahweh. Also cut off the lobe of the liver along with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron’s sons will lay them on top of the burnt offering on the burning wood. It is an offering by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your sacrifice is a fellowship offering of sheep to Yahweh, you must bring a male or female animal that has no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your offering is a lamb, you must bring it to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place your hand on the animal’s head. Slaughter it in front of the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons will throw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then take the fat from the fellowship offering and offer it by fire to Yahweh. Remove all the fat from the tail and the fat that covers the internal organs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also remove the two kidneys with the fat on them along with the lobe of the liver.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will burn the fellowship offering on the altar. It is food, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your offering is a goat, you must bring it to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Place your hand on its head. Slaughter it in front of the tent of meeting. Then Aaron’s sons will throw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring the fat that covers the internal organs
speaker: Narrator

text: and the two kidneys with the fat on them as an offering by fire to Yahweh. Also remove the lobe of the liver along with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will burn them on the altar. It is food, an offering by fire to the Lord. It is a soothing aroma. All the fat belongs to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a permanent law for generations to come wherever you live: Never eat any fat or blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If a person unintentionally does something wrong—even one thing that is forbidden by any of Yahweh’s commands—this is what he must do.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the anointed priest does something wrong and brings guilt on the people, he must bring a bull that has no defects as an offering for sin to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring the bull into Yahweh’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting. He will place his hand on the bull’s head. He will then slaughter the bull in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anointed priest will take some of the bull’s blood and bring it into the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will dip his finger in it and sprinkle some of the blood seven times in Yahweh’s presence facing the canopy in the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will put some of the blood on the horns of the altar for sweet-smelling incense in Yahweh’s presence in the tent of meeting. He will pour the rest of the bull’s blood at the bottom of the altar for burnt offerings at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will remove all of the fat from the bull that is the offering for sin, the fat that covers the internal organs,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the two kidneys with the fat on them. He will also remove the lobe of the liver and the kidneys
speaker: Narrator

text: the same way they were removed from the bull used for the fellowship offering. The priest will lay them on the altar for burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will take the entire bull (the skin, meat, head, legs, internal organs, and excrement)
speaker: Narrator

text: to a clean place outside the camp where the ashes are dumped. He will burn it there on a wood fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the whole congregation of Israel unintentionally does something wrong, without the assembly being aware of it, if they do even one thing that is forbidden by any of Yahweh’s commands, they will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wrong they have done becomes known, the congregation must sacrifice a bull as an offering for sin. They must bring it in front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of the congregation will place their hands on the bull’s head in Yahweh’s presence. One of them will slaughter it in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the anointed priest will bring some of the bull’s blood into the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will dip his finger in some of the blood and sprinkle it seven times in Yahweh’s presence facing the canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will also put some blood on the horns of the altar in Yahweh’s presence in the tent of meeting. He will pour the rest of the blood at the bottom of the altar for burnt offerings at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will remove all the fat and burn it on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will do the same thing with this bull that he did with the bull used as the offering for sin. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for the people, and they will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will take the bull outside the camp and will burn it the same way he burned the first bull. It is an offering for sin for the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a leader unintentionally does something wrong—even one thing that is forbidden by any of the commands of Yahweh his Elohim—he will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he is told about what he has done wrong, he must bring a male goat that has no defects as his offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will place his hand on the goat’s head and slaughter it in Yahweh’s presence where he slaughters animals for burnt offerings. It is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will take some of the blood of the offering for sin with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour the rest of the blood at the bottom of the altar for burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will burn all the fat on the altar the same way the fat of the fellowship offering is burned. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for what the leader did wrong, and the leader will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a common person unintentionally does something wrong—even one thing forbidden by Yahweh’s commands—he will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he is told about what he has done wrong, he must bring a female goat that has no defects as his offering for what he has done wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will place his hand on the animal’s head and slaughter it where animals for burnt offerings are slaughtered.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take some of the blood with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour the rest of the blood at the bottom of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will remove all the fat the same way it is removed from the fellowship offering. The priest will burn it on the altar for a soothing aroma to Yahweh. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for that person, and that person will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If someone brings a lamb as his offering for sin, he must bring a female that has no defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will place his hand on the animal’s head and slaughter it where he slaughters animals for burnt offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will take some of the blood from the offering for sin with his finger and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour the rest of the blood at the bottom of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will remove all the fat the same way the fat of the lamb is removed from the fellowship offerings. Then the priest will burn it on the altar with the offering by fire to Yahweh. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for what that person did wrong, and that person will be forgiven.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Now, if you are a witness under oath and won’t tell what you saw or what you know, you are sinning and will be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you touch anything unclean—the unclean dead body of a wild or tame animal or the body of an unclean, swarming creature—and then ignore what you did, you are unclean and will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you become unclean by touching human uncleanness of any kind and then ignore it (although you know what you did), you will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you hastily take a vow about what you will or will not do (as some people do) and then ignore it (although you know what you said), you will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So if you are guilty of any of these sins, you must confess it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring your guilt offering to Yahweh for the sin you committed. It must be a female sheep or goat as an offering for sin. Then the priest will make peace with the Lord for what you did wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, if you cannot afford a sheep, you must bring to Yahweh two mourning doves or two pigeons as a guilt offering for the sin you committed. One will be an offering for sin, the other a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring them to the priest, and he will sacrifice the offering for sin first. He will break the bird’s neck without pulling its head off.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will sprinkle some of the blood from the offering for sin on the side of the altar, and the rest of the blood will be drained at the bottom of the altar. It is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, following the proper procedures, he will sacrifice the second bird as a burnt offering. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for what you did wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if you cannot afford two mourning doves or two pigeons, then bring eight cups of flour as an offering for the sin you committed. Never put olive oil on it or add incense to it, because it is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring it to the priest. The priest will take a handful of it. He will burn it as a reminder on top of the offering by fire to Yahweh on the altar. It is an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest will make peace with the Lord for what you did wrong, and you will be forgiven. The offering will belong to the priest like the grain offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “If any of you fail to do your duty by unintentionally doing something wrong with any of Yahweh’s holy things, bring a guilt offering to Yahweh. It must be a ram that has no defects or its value in silver weighed according to the official standards of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay for whatever holy things you used plus one-fifth more. Give it to the priest. So the priest will use the ram sacrificed for the guilt offering to make peace with the Lord for what you did wrong, and you will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If any of you do wrong—even one thing forbidden by any of Yahweh’s commands, but you didn’t know it—when you realize your guilt, you must be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must bring the priest a ram that has no defects from the flock or its value in money for a guilt offering. The priest will make peace with the Lord for the wrong you did unintentionally (although you didn’t know what you did), and you will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a guilt offering because you are certainly guilty as far as Yahweh is concerned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “If any of you sin against Yahweh by failing to do your duty, if you lie to your neighbor about something you were supposed to take care of or if you lie about something stolen or seized from your neighbor, you are sinning and will be guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you find something that someone lost and lie about it under oath, or commit any other sin like this,
speaker: Narrator

text: you are sinning and will be guilty. Return what you stole or seized, what you were supposed to take care of, the lost item you found,
speaker: Narrator

text: or whatever it was that you swore falsely about. Pay it back in full plus one-fifth more. Give it back to its owner on the day you bring your guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then bring Yahweh your guilt offering, a ram that has no defects or its value in money. Bring it to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priest will make peace with the Lord. Then you will be forgiven for whatever you did that made you guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command Aaron and his sons: These are the instructions for the burnt offering that stays on the altar overnight while the altar fire is kept burning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest must put on his linen clothes, including his linen undergarments. Then he will remove the ashes left on the altar from the fire that consumed the burnt offering and will put them next to the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will take off these clothes and put on some others. He will take the ashes to a clean place outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fire must always be burning on the altar. It must never go out. The priest will burn wood on it every morning. He will lay the burnt offering on the fire and burn the fat of the fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fire must always be burning on the altar. It must never go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for the grain offering. Aaron’s sons must bring it into Yahweh’s presence in front of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: One of them will remove a handful of flour from the grain offering, together with the olive oil and all the incense. He will burn it on the altar as a reminder. It is a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron and his sons will eat the rest of it. They will eat unleavened bread in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t use yeast in baking the bread. I have given it to them as their share from the offerings by fire made to me. It is very holy like the offering for sin and the guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every male descendant of Aaron may eat it. It is a permanent law for generations to come regarding the offering by fire to Yahweh. Everyone who touches it will become holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the offering that Aaron and his sons must bring to Yahweh on the day he is anointed—eight cups of flour. They must do this every day. He must offer half of it in the morning and half in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare it in a frying pan with olive oil, mixing it well. Offer baked pieces of the grain offering as a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s son who is anointed to take his place as priest will prepare it. This is a permanent law of Yahweh: It must be completely burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering made by a priest must be completely burned. It must not be eaten.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons: These are the instructions for the offering for sin. The offering for sin must be slaughtered in Yahweh’s presence in the same place where the burnt offering is slaughtered. It is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who makes the offering for sin will eat it in a holy place, in the courtyard of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything that touches its meat will be holy. If blood gets on someone’s clothes, he must wash them in a holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any piece of pottery in which the offering for sin is cooked must be broken into pieces. Any copper kettle in which the offering for sin is cooked must be scoured and rinsed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male among the priests may eat the offering for sin. It is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any offering for sin must not be eaten if some of the blood was brought into the holy place in the tent of meeting to make peace with the Lord. It must be burned.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “These are the instructions for the guilt offering. It is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: It must be slaughtered in the same place where the burnt offering is slaughtered. A priest will throw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will offer all the fat, the fat from the tail, the fat covering the internal organs,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the two kidneys with the fat on them. He will also remove the lobe of the liver along with the kidneys.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will burn them on the altar. It is a guilt offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any male among the priests may eat it. It will be eaten in a holy place. It is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The same instructions apply to the offering for sin and the guilt offering. Both offerings belong to the priest to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The skin of the burnt offering belongs to the priest who sacrifices it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering, whether baked in an oven or prepared in a skillet or a frying pan, belongs to the priest who offers it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every grain offering, whether mixed with olive oil or dry, will be shared equally by all of Aaron’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for the fellowship offering that you must bring to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you offer it as a thank offering, you must also bring rings of unleavened bread mixed with olive oil, wafers of unleavened bread brushed with olive oil, and loaves made from flour mixed well with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to these rings of bread, you must bring bread with yeast along with your fellowship offering of thanksgiving.
speaker: Narrator

text: From every offering you must bring one loaf to Yahweh as a special contribution. It will belong to the priest who throws the blood of the fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The meat from your fellowship offering of thanksgiving must be eaten on the day it is offered. Never leave any of it until morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your sacrificial offering is something you vowed or a freewill offering, it must be eaten the day you offer it or the next day.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, on the third day any meat left over from the sacrifice must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not be accepted if any meat from the fellowship offering is eaten on the third day. You will not receive credit for it. It is repulsive to Elohim. The person who eats any of it must be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Meat that touches anything unclean must not be eaten. It must be burned. Anyone who is clean may eat from these sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat meat from Yahweh’s fellowship offering while unclean must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch anything unclean, human or animal, or any other disgusting uncleanness and still eat Yahweh’s fellowship offering must be excluded from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: Never eat any fat from bulls, sheep, or goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fat from an animal that dies naturally or is killed by wild animals you may use for any other purpose, but you must never eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat the fat from an animal which they sacrificed by fire to Yahweh must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never eat the blood of any bird or animal no matter where you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat any blood must be excluded from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: Anyone who offers Yahweh a fellowship offering must bring a part of that sacrifice as a gift to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring the sacrifices by fire made to Yahweh yourself. Bring the fat with the breast. Take the breast and present it to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest will burn the fat on the altar. However, the breast will belong to Aaron and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will also give the priest the right thigh as a contribution.
speaker: Narrator

text: When any of Aaron’s sons offer the blood and fat of the fellowship offering, the right thigh will belong to him as his share.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the fellowship offerings of the Israelites, I have taken the breast that was presented to me and the thigh from the contribution offering. I have given them to the priest Aaron and his sons. This is a permanent law for generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the share for Aaron and his sons from the sacrifices by fire made to Yahweh. It was given to them on the day Moses ordained them to serve Yahweh as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh commanded the Israelites to give it to them on the day he anointed them. This is a permanent law for generations to come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the instructions for the burnt offering, the grain offering, the offering for sin, the guilt offering, the ordination offering, and the fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On Mount Sinai Yahweh gave Moses commands about these offerings at the same time that he commanded the Israelites to bring their offerings to Yahweh in the Sinai Desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take Aaron and his sons, the priests’ clothes, the anointing oil, the bull that will be the offering for sin, the two rams, and the basket of unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: Gather the whole congregation at the entrance to the tent of meeting.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses did as Yahweh commanded him, and the congregation gathered at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told the congregation, “Yahweh has commanded that this is what you must do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses had Aaron and his sons come forward, and he washed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the linen robe on Aaron and fastened the belt around him. He also dressed him in the robe that is worn with the ephod. He fastened the ephod to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he put the breastplate on him, and into it he placed the Urim and Thummim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put the turban on him and fastened the gold medallion (the holy crown) to the front of the turban as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took the anointing oil to anoint the tent and everything in it and dedicate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sprinkled some of the oil on the altar seven times and anointed the altar, all the utensils, and the basin with its stand to dedicate them.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also poured some of the anointing oil on Aaron’s head and anointed him to set him apart for his holy duties.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses had Aaron’s sons come forward. He put linen robes on them, fastened their belts around them, and put turbans on them as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the bull that was the offering for sin. Aaron and his sons placed their hands on its head.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was slaughtered, Moses took the blood and put it on the horns of the altar all around with his finger and cleansed the altar from sins. He poured the rest of the blood at the bottom of the altar and declared it holy so that priests could use it to make peace with the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took all the fat that was on the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys with their fat, and he burned them on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned the rest of the bull, its skin, meat, and excrement outside the camp, as Yahweh commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought forward the ram for the burnt offering. Aaron and his sons placed their hands on the ram’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses slaughtered it and threw the blood against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ram was cut into pieces, Moses burned the head with the other pieces and the fat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He washed the internal organs and the legs. Then Moses burned the whole ram on the altar as Yahweh commanded him. It was a burnt offering, a soothing aroma, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought forward the second ram for the ordination offering. Aaron and his sons placed their hands on the ram’s head.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses slaughtered it, took some of the blood, and put it on Aaron’s right ear lobe, on his right thumb, and on the big toe of his right foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also brought Aaron’s sons forward. He put some of the blood on their right ear lobes, on their right thumbs, and on the big toes of their right feet. Moses threw the rest of the blood against all the sides of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took the fat, the fat from the tail, all the fat on the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys with their fat, and the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took a loaf of unleavened bread, a ring of bread made with olive oil, and a wafer from the basket of unleavened bread which was in Yahweh’s presence. He put them on the fat and the right thigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed all these things in the hands of Aaron and his sons. Moses presented all these things to Yahweh as an offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he took them from their hands and burned them on top of the burnt offering on the altar. These were ordination offerings, offerings by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses also took the breast from the ram of the ordination offering and presented it to Yahweh. It was Moses’ share, as Yahweh had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses took some of the anointing oil and some of the blood that was on the altar, sprinkled it on Aaron and his clothes and on his sons and their clothes. In this way he dedicated Aaron, his clothes, his sons, and their clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron and his sons: “Cook the meat at the entrance to the tent of meeting. Take the meat and the bread in the basket of the ordination offering. Eat them there as I commanded when I said, ‘Aaron and his sons will eat it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You must burn any meat or bread that is left over.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will not leave the entrance to the tent of meeting for seven days, not until the last day of your ordination is over. It will take seven days to ordain you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I did today what Yahweh commanded me to make peace with the Lord for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will stay at the entrance to the tent of meeting day and night for seven days and serve as Yahweh tells you. Then you will not die. This is what I was commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron and his sons did everything Yahweh commanded through Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day Moses summoned Aaron and his sons and the leaders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told Aaron, “Take a calf that has no defects for yourself as an offering for sin and a ram that has no defects as a burnt offering. Sacrifice them in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also tell the Israelites: ‘Take a male goat as an offering for sin, a calf and a lamb (each one year old and without defects) as a burnt offering,
speaker: Narrator

text: a bull and a ram as a fellowship offering, and a grain offering mixed with olive oil to sacrifice in Yahweh’s presence. Yahweh will appear to you today.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took the things Moses commanded and brought them in front of the tent of meeting. The whole congregation came and stood in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said, “Yahweh has commanded you to offer these sacrifices so that you may see Yahweh’s glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron, “Come to the altar and sacrifice an offering for sin and a burnt offering to make peace with the Lord for your sins and the sins of the people. Also make an offering for the people, to make peace with the Lord for them as Yahweh commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron came to the altar and slaughtered the calf as his own offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s sons brought him the blood. He dipped his finger in the blood and put it on the horns of the altar. Then he poured out the blood at the bottom of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the altar he burned the fat, kidneys, and lobe of the liver from the offering for sin as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He burned the meat and the skin outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slaughtered the animal for the burnt offering. Aaron’s sons gave him the blood, and he threw it against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also gave him the burnt offering, which was cut in pieces and included the head. He burned it on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He washed the internal organs and the legs and laid them on top of the burnt offering on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought the people’s offerings. He took the male goat for the people’s offering for sin and slaughtered it. He sacrificed it to take away sins as he had done before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Following the proper procedures, he brought forward the burnt offering and sacrificed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also brought the grain offering. He took a handful of grain and burned it on the altar in addition to the morning burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He slaughtered the bull and the ram for the people’s fellowship offering. Aaron’s sons gave him the blood, which he threw against the altar on all sides.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the fat from the bull and the ram (the fat from the tail, the layer of fat, the kidneys, and the lobe of the liver)
speaker: Narrator

text: they placed on the breasts. Aaron burned them all on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, he first took the breasts and the right thighs and presented them to Yahweh as Moses commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron raised his hands toward the people and blessed them. He sacrificed the offering for sin, the burnt offering, and the fellowship offering. Then he came down from the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses and Aaron went into the tent of meeting. When they came out, they blessed the people. Then Yahweh’s glory appeared to all the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Fire came out from Yahweh’s presence and consumed the burnt offering and the pieces of fat on the altar. When all the people saw this, they shouted and bowed with their faces touching the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron’s sons Nadab and Abihu each took an incense burner and put burning coals and incense in it. Then in Yahweh’s presence they offered this unauthorized fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: A fire flashed from Yahweh and burned them, and they died in the presence of Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moses said to Aaron, “This is exactly what Yahweh said:
‘I will show my holiness among those who come to me.
I will show my glory to all the people.’”
Aaron was speechless.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses called Mishael and Elzaphan, the sons of Aaron’s uncle, Uzziel. He told them, “Come and take your relatives away from in front of the holy place. Take them outside the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they came and took them away to a place outside the camp, as Moses told them. The dead men were still in their linen robes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron and his sons Eleazar and Ithamar: “Do not mourn by leaving your hair uncombed or tearing your clothes. If you do, you will die and Yahweh will become angry with the whole congregation. All the other Israelites may cry over the fire Yahweh sent, but you may not.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not leave the entrance to the tent of meeting or else you, too, will die, because Yahweh has anointed you with his oil.” They obeyed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “You and your sons must not drink any wine or liquor when you go into the tent of meeting, or you will die. This is a permanent law for generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Teach them the difference between what is holy and what is unholy, what is clean and what is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also teach the Israelites all the laws that Yahweh gave them through Moses.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told Aaron and his surviving sons Eleazar and Ithamar, “Take the grain offering left over from the offering by fire to Yahweh. Make unleavened bread, and eat it next to the altar because it is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it in a holy place because it is the part of the offering by fire to Yahweh that belongs to you and your children. That is the command I received.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also eat the breast presented to the Lord and the thigh that was given as a contribution. You and your sons and daughters may eat them in a clean place because they are your part of the fellowship offerings from the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will bring the thigh given as a contribution, the breast presented to the Lord, and the fat that is to be burned and present them to Yahweh. These parts will belong to you and your children. This will be a permanent law, as Yahweh has commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses tried to find out what had happened to the male goat that was supposed to be the offering for sin. To his surprise, it had already been burned. So he became angry with Eleazar and Ithamar, Aaron’s surviving sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: He asked them, “Why didn’t you eat the offering for sin in the holy place? It is very holy and was given to you to take away the sins of the congregation and to make peace with the Lord for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Since its blood was not brought inside the holy place, you certainly should have eaten it there, as I commanded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron answered Moses, “Today they sacrificed their offering for sin and their burnt offering in Yahweh’s presence, and look what happened to me. If I had eaten the offering for sin today, would Yahweh have approved?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard this, he was satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: Here are the kinds of land animals you may eat:
speaker: Narrator

text: all animals that have completely divided hoofs and that also chew their cud.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, from those that either chew their cud or have divided hoofs, these are the kinds you must never eat: You must never eat camels. (Camels are unclean because they chew their cud but do not have divided hoofs.)
speaker: Narrator

text: You must never eat rock badgers. (Rock badgers are unclean because they chew their cud but do not have divided hoofs.)
speaker: Narrator

text: You must never eat rabbits. (Rabbits are unclean because they chew their cud but do not have divided hoofs.)
speaker: Narrator

text: You must never eat pigs. (Because pigs have completely divided hoofs but do not chew their cud, they are also unclean.)
speaker: Narrator

text: Never eat the meat of these animals or touch their dead bodies. They are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here are the kinds of creatures that live in the water which you may eat—anything in the seas and streams that has fins and scales.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you must consider all swarming creatures living in the seas or the streams that have no fins or scales disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must remain disgusting to you. Never eat their meat. Consider their dead bodies disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every creature in the water without fins or scales is disgusting to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here are the kinds of birds you must consider disgusting and must not eat. They are eagles, bearded vultures, black vultures,
speaker: Narrator

text: kites, all types of buzzards,
speaker: Narrator

text: all types of crows,
speaker: Narrator

text: ostriches, nighthawks, seagulls, all types of falcons,
speaker: Narrator

text: little owls, cormorants, great owls,
speaker: Narrator

text: barn owls, pelicans, ospreys,
speaker: Narrator

text: storks, all types of herons, hoopoes, and bats.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every swarming, winged insect that walks across the ground like a four-legged animal is disgusting to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you may eat winged insects that swarm if they use their legs to hop on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may eat any kind of locust, cricket, katydid, or grasshopper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every kind of winged insect that walks across the ground like a four-legged animal is disgusting to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Regarding the creatures mentioned above, this is how you would become unclean: Whoever touches their dead bodies will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever carries any part of their dead bodies must wash his clothes. He will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: All animals whose hoofs are not completely divided or that don’t chew their cud are unclean for you. Whoever touches them is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: All four-legged animals that walk on their paws are unclean for you. Whoever touches their dead bodies will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who carry the dead body of any of these animals must wash their clothes and will be unclean until evening. These animals are unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The following swarming creatures that move on the ground are unclean for you—moles, mice, and all types of lizards:
speaker: Narrator

text: geckos, monitors, lizards, skinks, and chameleons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among all the swarming creatures that move on the ground, these are unclean for you. Whoever touches their dead bodies will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the dead body of one of these creatures falls on something, that thing will be unclean. It may be a wooden article, clothing, leather, a sack, or anything used for any purpose. It should be put in water and will be unclean until evening. Then it will be clean again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If any of these creatures falls into a piece of pottery, break the pottery because everything in it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If water from that pottery touches any food, the food is unclean. Any liquid that you drink from that pottery is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anything on which their dead bodies fall is unclean. If it is an oven or a stove, smash it. It is unclean and will remain unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, a spring or a cistern holding water will remain clean. But anyone who touches their dead bodies will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If their dead bodies fall on seed that is to be planted, the seed is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if water is poured on the seed and their dead bodies fall on it, the seed is unclean for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When any animal that you are allowed to eat dies, whoever touches its dead body will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat any of its dead body must wash their clothes and will be unclean until evening. Those who carry its dead body away will wash their clothes and will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any creature that swarms on the ground is disgusting and must not be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t eat any creature with many legs that goes on its belly or on the ground like a four-legged animal, or any creature that swarms on the ground. Consider them disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t become disgusting by eating anything that swarms on the ground. Never allow yourselves to become unclean because of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Here is the reason: I am Yahweh your Elohim. You must live holy lives. Be holy because I am holy. Never become unclean by touching anything that swarms or crawls on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is the reason again: I am Yahweh. I brought you out of Egypt to be your Elohim. Be holy because I am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions about animals, birds, and every living creature that swims in the water and every creature that swarms on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: These instructions help you distinguish between clean and unclean, the animals you may eat and those you may not eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: When a woman gives birth to a boy, she will be unclean for seven days. This is the same number of days she is unclean for her monthly period.
speaker: Narrator

text: The boy must be circumcised when he is eight days old.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she must stay at home for 33 days in order to be made clean from her bleeding. She must not touch anything holy or go into the holy place until the days needed to make her clean are over.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a woman gives birth to a girl, she will be unclean as in her monthly period. However, she will be unclean for two weeks. Then she must stay at home for 66 days in order to be made clean from her bleeding.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When the days needed to make her clean are over, she must bring a one-year-old lamb for a burnt offering and a pigeon or a mourning dove as an offering for sin. She must bring them to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The priest will offer them in Yahweh’s presence to make peace with the Lord for her. Then she will be clean from her flow of blood.
“These are the instructions for the woman who gives birth to a boy or a girl.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she cannot afford a lamb, she must use two mourning doves or two pigeons. One will be the burnt offering and the other the offering for sin. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for her, and she will be clean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone has a sore, a rash, or an irritated area on his skin that turns into an infectious skin disease, he must be taken to the priest Aaron or to one of his sons who are also priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine the disease. If the hair in the diseased area has turned white, and the diseased area looks deeper than the rest of his skin, it is an infectious skin disease. When the priest has examined him, he must declare him unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the irritated area is white and does not look deeper than the rest of the skin, and the hair has not turned white, the priest must put him in isolation for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will examine him again. If the disease looks the same and has not spread, the priest must put him in isolation for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will examine him again. If the diseased area has faded and not spread, the priest must declare him clean. It is only a rash. The person must wash his clothes and will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the rash has spread after he has shown himself to the priest to be declared clean, he must show himself to the priest again.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine him one more time, and if the rash has spread, the priest must declare him unclean. It is an infectious skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone has an infectious skin disease, he must be taken to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine him. If there is a white sore that has turned the hair white, and if there is raw flesh in the sore,
speaker: Narrator

text: he has a chronic skin disease. Without putting him in isolation, the priest must declare him unclean because he is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If skin disease develops and covers the whole person from head to foot (so far as the priest can see),
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will examine him. If the disease does cover his whole body, the priest must declare the diseased person clean. His body has turned white. The person is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if raw flesh appears, he will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine the raw flesh and declare him unclean. The raw flesh is unclean. It is an infectious skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the raw flesh turns white again, he must go to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine him again, and if the diseased area has turned white, the priest must declare the diseased person clean. He is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a boil on the skin has healed
speaker: Narrator

text: and in its place there is a white sore or a pink area, it must be shown to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine it. If it looks deeper than the rest of the skin and its hair has turned white, the priest must declare the person unclean. An infectious skin disease has developed in the boil.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines the affected area and the hair in it is not white or the affected area is not deeper than the rest of the skin but has faded, the priest must put him in isolation for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the area has spread, the priest must declare him unclean. It is a skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the irritated area has not spread, it is a scar caused by the boil. The priest must declare him clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone has a burn on his skin and the raw flesh of the burn turns into a pink or bright white area,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will examine it. If the hair on the affected area has turned white and the affected area looks deeper than the rest of the skin, an infectious skin disease has developed in the burn. The priest must declare him unclean. It is an infectious skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines it and the hair in it is not white and the affected area is not deeper than the rest of the skin but has faded, the priest must put him in isolation for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will examine him again. If the area has spread, the priest must declare him unclean. It is an infectious skin disease.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the irritated area does not spread but has faded, it is only a sore caused by the burn. The priest must declare him clean, because it is a scar caused by the burn.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man or a woman has some disease on the head or chin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will examine the disease. If it looks deeper than the rest of the skin and there is thin yellow hair on it, the priest must declare the person unclean. It is a scab, a disease on the head or the chin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest examines the scabby disease and it does not look deeper than the rest of the skin and there is no black hair in it, the priest must put the person with the scabby disease in isolation for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will examine the disease. If the scab has not spread, there is no yellow hair on it, and the scab does not look deeper than the rest of the skin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the person will shave everything except the scab. The priest will put the person with the scab in isolation for another seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will examine the scab again. If the scab has not spread on the skin and does not look deeper than the rest of the skin, the priest must declare him clean. When he has washed his clothes, he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the scab spreads after the person has been declared clean,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will make another examination. If the scab has spread on the skin, the priest does not have to look for yellow hair. The person is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he sees that the scab hasn’t spread and black hair grows on it, the scab is healed. The person is clean, so the priest must declare him clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man or a woman has white irritated areas of skin,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will make an examination. If the irritated areas on the skin are pale white, a rash has developed on the skin. The person is clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man loses his hair, he is clean, even though he is bald.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he loses the hair on the front of his head, he is clean, even though he is bald on the forehead.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if there is a pink patch on the bald places in back or in front, a skin disease is developing in those places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine him. If the sore from the disease in the bald places in back or in front is pink like a skin disease somewhere else on the body,
speaker: Narrator

text: the man has come down with an infectious skin disease. He is unclean. The priest must declare him unclean because of the skin disease on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: “People who come down with a skin disease must wear torn clothes and leave their hair uncombed. They must cover their upper lips and call out, ‘Unclean, unclean!’
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as they have the skin disease, they are unclean. They must live outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now about clothing—if there is a green or red area on a piece of clothing
speaker: Narrator

text: that is woven or knitted from linen or wool or on any leather article,
speaker: Narrator

text: it is mildew. It must be shown to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine the mildew and will put the clothing in a separate place for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day he will examine the area again. If the spot is spreading, it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must burn the piece of clothing or the leather article because the mildew is growing.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest sees that the area has not spread,
speaker: Narrator

text: he must order the area to be washed and put the clothing in a separate place for seven more days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will examine the area again after it is washed. If it doesn’t look any different and the mildew has not spread, it is still unclean. It must be burned, whether the area is on the outside or the inside.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the priest sees that the area is pale after washing, he will tear it out of the clothing or the leather.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if it shows up again, you must burn the clothing or the leather article.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the area disappears from the woven or knitted clothing or any leather article when it is washed, wash it again, and it will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for deciding whether mildew in clothing that is woven or knitted from linen or wool or in any leather article is clean or unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for making a person clean after a skin disease. He must be taken to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will go outside the camp and examine him. If the person is healed,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will order someone to get two living, clean birds, some cedar wood, red yarn, and a hyssop sprig to use for the cleansing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will order someone to kill one bird over a clay bowl containing fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take the living bird, the cedar wood, the red yarn, and the hyssop sprig and dip them and the living bird in the blood of the bird that was killed over the fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will sprinkle the blood seven times on the one to be cleansed and will declare that person clean. Then he will let the living bird fly away into the open country.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The one to be cleansed must wash his clothes, shave off all his hair, and wash. Then he will be clean. After that he may go into the camp. However, for seven days he will live outside his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day he must shave off all the hair on his head, his beard, and his eyebrows, and he must wash his clothes and body. Then he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “On the eighth day he must take two male lambs that have no defects and a one-year-old female lamb that has no defects. He must also take eight cups of flour mixed with olive oil for a grain offering along with a quart of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who will declare him clean must bring the person and his offerings into Yahweh’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take one of the male lambs and the quart of olive oil and present them to Yahweh as a guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will slaughter the lamb in the holy place where he slaughters the offering for sin and the burnt offering. He will do this because the guilt offering, like the offering for sin, belongs to the priest. It is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest will take some of the blood from the guilt offering and put it on the right ear lobe, on the right thumb, and on the big toe of the right foot of the one to be cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will also take some of the olive oil and pour it into his own left hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will dip his right finger in the oil in his left hand, and with his finger sprinkle some of the oil seven times in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will put some of the oil that is still in his hand on the right ear lobe, on the right thumb, and on the big toe of the right foot of the one to be cleansed. These are the same places he had put the blood of the guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will put the rest of the oil in his hand on the head of the one to be cleansed. So he will make peace with the Lord for that person in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will also sacrifice the offering for sin to make peace with the Lord for the one who is being cleansed from his impurity. After that, he will slaughter the burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will sacrifice the burnt offering and the grain offering on the altar. So the priest will make peace with the Lord for that person, and the person who had the skin disease will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if the one to be cleansed is poor and cannot afford that much, he must take one male lamb, present it to make peace with the Lord for himself, and use it for his guilt offering. He will take only eight cups of flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering, a quart of olive oil,
speaker: Narrator

text: and two mourning doves or two pigeons (whatever he can afford). The one will be an offering for sin and the other a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he will take them to the priest for his cleansing at the entrance to the tent of meeting in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will take the lamb for the guilt offering and the quart of olive oil and present them to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will slaughter the lamb as a guilt offering. Then the priest will take some of the blood of the guilt offering and put it on the right ear lobe, on the right thumb, and on the big toe of the right foot of the one to be cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will pour some of the olive oil into his own left hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his right finger he will sprinkle some of the oil seven times in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will put some of the oil that is in his hand on the right ear lobe, on the right thumb, and on the big toe of the right foot of the one to be cleansed. These are the same places he had put the blood of the guilt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Yahweh’s presence, the priest will pour the rest of the oil in his hand on the head of the one to be cleansed in order to make a payment for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the one to be cleansed must take one of the mourning doves or pigeons (whichever he can afford),
speaker: Narrator

text: and sacrifice it as an offering for sin. He will take the other and sacrifice it as a burnt offering together with the grain offering. So in Yahweh’s presence the priest will make peace with the Lord for the one who is being cleansed.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the instructions for one who has an infectious skin disease but cannot afford what is needed for his cleansing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you come to Canaan that I am going to give to you, mildew may appear in a house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The owner of that house must come and tell the priest that there is something that looks like mildew in his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Before the priest examines the house, he will order everything taken out of it so that nothing in the house will become unclean. Then the priest will go inside to examine the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will examine the mildew area on the walls. If it is green and red in sunken areas that are deeper than the rest of the wall,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will go out to the door of the house and close up the house for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day the priest will go back and examine it again. If the mildew in the walls of the house has spread,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest must order the stones that have the mildew to be torn out and thrown outside the city in an unclean place.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must have the entire inside of the house scraped. The plaster dust scraped off the walls must be dumped in an unclean place outside the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stones must be replaced, and the house must be plastered again.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the mildew develops again in the house after all this,
speaker: Narrator

text: the priest will examine it one more time. If it is a spreading type of mildew, the house is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The house—stones, wood, and all the plaster—must be torn down and taken to an unclean place outside the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever goes into the house any time it is closed up will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever sleeps or eats in the house must wash his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the priest comes and makes an examination and the mildew has not spread in the house after it is plastered again, the priest must declare the house clean. The mildew is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest must take two birds, cedar wood, red yarn, and a hyssop sprig and use them to make the house clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must kill the one bird over a clay bowl containing fresh water.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must take the cedar wood, the hyssop sprig, the red yarn, and the living bird and dip them in the fresh water containing the blood of the bird that was killed. He must sprinkle the house seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he must use the bird’s blood, the fresh water, the living bird, the cedar wood, the hyssop, and the red yarn to make the house clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will let the living bird fly from the city into the open country. He will make peace with the Lord for the house, and it will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for any kind of mildew or fungus
speaker: Narrator

text: that infects clothing or houses
speaker: Narrator

text: and for skin diseases where there is a sore, a rash, or an irritated area.
speaker: Narrator

text: These instructions for skin diseases and mildew help you distinguish between what is clean and what is unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses and Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If a man has a discharge from his penis, his discharge is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is unclean because of the discharge from his penis. Whether it is chronic or not makes no difference; he is still unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who has a discharge makes everything he lies on or sits on unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch his bed must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who sit on anything he sat on must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch a man who has a discharge must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man who has a discharge spits on anyone who is clean, the person he spits on must wash his clothes and his body. He will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man who has a discharge sits on a saddle, it becomes unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who carry such things must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man who has a discharge touches anyone without first rinsing his hands, the person he touched must wash his clothes and his body. He will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man who has a discharge touches pottery, it must be broken, and any wooden bucket he touches must be rinsed.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man’s discharge stops, he must wait seven days to be cleansed. He must wash his clothes and his body in fresh water. Then he will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day he must take two mourning doves or two pigeons and come into Yahweh’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting. He will give these birds to the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will sacrifice one as an offering for sin and the other as a burnt offering. So in Yahweh’s presence, the priest will make peace with the Lord for the man who had a discharge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man has an emission of semen, he must bathe his whole body. He will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Any clothes or any leather with semen on it must be washed. It will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a man has sexual intercourse with a woman and has an emission of semen, they must wash themselves. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a woman has her monthly period, she will be unclean for seven days. Those who touch her will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything she lies on or sits on during her period will be unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch her bed must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch anything she sits on must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If her blood touches anything on the bed or anything she sits on, it will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has sexual intercourse with her while she has her period, he will be unclean for seven days. Any bed he lies on will become unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a woman has a discharge of blood for many days other than her monthly period, she is unclean. If her period lasts longer than usual, she will be unclean as long as she has a discharge. It is like her period.
speaker: Narrator

text: As long as she has a discharge, any bed she lies on or anything she sits on is unclean. It is like her period.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who touch these things are unclean and must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When her discharge stops, she must wait seven days. After that, she will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the eighth day she must take two mourning doves or two pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will offer one as an offering for sin and the other as a burnt offering. So in Yahweh’s presence the priest will make peace with the Lord for the woman who had an unclean discharge.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You must separate the Israelites from anything that keeps them from being presentable to me. Otherwise, they will die because they make my tent, which is among them, unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are the instructions for any man who has a discharge or an emission of semen that makes him unclean,
speaker: Narrator

text: for any woman who has her period, for any man or woman who has a discharge, or for any man who has sexual intercourse with a woman when she is unclean.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses after Aaron’s two sons had come into Yahweh’s presence and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh said, “Tell your brother Aaron that he cannot go into the holy place whenever he wants to. If he goes up to the canopy and stands in front of the throne of mercy on the ark, he will die, because I appear in the smoke above the throne of mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what Aaron must do in order to come into the holy place: He must take a bull as an offering for sin and a ram as a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must put on a holy linen robe and wear linen undergarments. He must wear a linen belt and turban. These are holy clothes. He must wash his body and put them on.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take two male goats from the congregation of Israel as an offering for sin and a ram as a burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron must sacrifice the bull as his own offering for sin. By doing this, he will make peace with the Lord for himself and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must take the two male goats and bring them into Yahweh’s presence at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron must throw lots for the two goats. One lot will be for Yahweh and the other for Azazel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron must sacrifice the goat chosen by lot for Yahweh as an offering for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he must bring the goat chosen by lot for Azazel into Yahweh’s presence. He will release it in the desert to Azazel in order to make peace with the Lord for himself and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron will bring the bull. He will then slaughter it as his own offering for sin. By doing this he will make peace with the Lord for himself and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take an incense burner full of burning coals from the altar, which is in Yahweh’s presence, and two handfuls of finely ground, sweet-smelling incense. He will bring them up to the canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will put the incense on the fire in Yahweh’s presence. The cloud of incense will cover the throne of mercy, which is over the words of God’s promise, so that he will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will take some of the bull’s blood and sprinkle it with his finger on the east side of the throne of mercy. Then he will sprinkle some of the blood with his finger seven times in front of the throne of mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Next, Aaron will slaughter the goat for the people’s offering for sin. He will take the blood inside, go up to the canopy, and sprinkle it on the throne of mercy and in front of it, as he did with the bull’s blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he will make peace with the Lord for all the sins the Israelites committed against the holy place. These sins happened because the Israelites were unclean and because they committed rebellious acts. He will do the same for the tent of meeting which is among an unclean people.
speaker: Narrator

text: No one may be in the tent of meeting from the time Aaron enters the holy place to do this until he comes out. Aaron will make peace with the Lord for his own sins, his family’s sins, and the sins of the entire assembly of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he will go out to the altar that is in Yahweh’s presence and make peace with the Lord there for the sins committed. He will take some of the blood from the bull and some of the goat’s blood and put it all around the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his finger he will sprinkle some of the blood on it seven times. Because the Israelites made it unclean, he will cleanse it and declare it holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When he finishes making peace with the Lord at the holy place, the tent of meeting, and the altar, he will bring the living goat forward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron will place both hands on its head. He will confess over it all the sins, all the rebellious acts, and all the things the Israelites did wrong. He will transfer them to the goat’s head. A man will be appointed to release the goat in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: The goat will take all their sins away to a deserted place. The man must release the goat in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then Aaron will go to the tent of meeting, take off the linen clothes he had put on to go into the holy place, and leave them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will wash his body in the holy place and put on his other clothes. Then he will come out and sacrifice the burnt offering for himself and for the people to make peace with the Lord for his own sins and the sins of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will burn the fat of the offering for sin on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who released the goat to Azazel must wash his clothes and his body. Then he may return to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must take the bull and the goat outside the camp. These animals were the offering for sin whose blood was brought into the holy place to make peace with the Lord for sins. The skin, meat, and excrement from the animals must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever burns them must wash his clothes and his body. Then he may return to the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This will be a permanent law for you: On the tenth day of the seventh month both native Israelites and foreigners must humble themselves. They must do no work.
speaker: Narrator

text: On this day Aaron will make peace with the Lord to make you clean. Then you will be clean from all your sins in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the most important worship festival there is for you. You will humble yourselves. It is a permanent law.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest who is anointed and ordained to serve as chief priest in his father’s place will pay for sins. He will put on the holy linen clothes
speaker: Narrator

text: and will make peace with the Lord at the holy place, the tent of meeting, and the altar. He will make peace with the Lord for the priests and all the worshipers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This permanent law tells you how to make peace with the Lord once a year for all the sins the Israelites committed.”
Aaron did as Yahweh had commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelites that this is what Yahweh has commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: Any Israelite who slaughters a bull, sheep, or goat inside or outside the camp
speaker: Narrator

text: is guilty of bloodshed. He has shed blood and must be excluded from the people. Bring the animal to the entrance of the tent of meeting. Offer it to Yahweh in front of Yahweh’s tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: This means that the people of Israel must take the sacrifices they have been making in the open fields and bring them to Yahweh. They must bring them to the priest at the entrance to the tent of meeting. The people will sacrifice them as fellowship offerings to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will pour the blood against Yahweh’s altar at the entrance to the tent of meeting. He will burn the fat as a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people must stop sacrificing to goat idols and chasing after them as though they were prostitutes. This is a permanent law for the people and for future generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them: If Israelites or foreigners make burnt offerings or sacrifices
speaker: Narrator

text: but do not bring them to the entrance of the tent of meeting to offer them to Yahweh, they must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If Israelites or foreigners eat any blood, I will condemn them and exclude them from the people,
speaker: Narrator

text: because blood contains life. I have given this blood to you to make peace with me on the altar. Blood is needed to make peace with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: That is why I have said to the people of Israel: Neither you nor foreigners should ever eat blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If Israelites or foreigners hunt any animal or bird that may be eaten, they must pour out the animal’s blood and cover it with dirt.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is because the life of any creature is in its blood. So I have said to the people of Israel: Never eat any blood, because the life of any creature is in its blood. Whoever eats blood must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Native Israelites or foreigners who eat the body of an animal that dies naturally or is killed by another animal must wash their clothes and their bodies. They will be unclean until evening. Then they will be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If they don’t wash their clothes and their bodies, they will be guilty of sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
