speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: You used to live in Egypt. Don’t live the way the Egyptians do. I am bringing you to Canaan. Don’t live the way the Canaanites do. Never live by their standards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Follow my rules, and live by my standards. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live by my standards, and obey my rules. You will have life through them. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never have sexual intercourse with anyone related to you by blood. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never have sexual intercourse with your mother. She is your own mother. Never have sexual intercourse with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your stepmother. She is related to you through your father.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your stepsister, whether she is your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter. It makes no difference whether or not she was born in your house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your granddaughter, whether she is your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter, because she is related to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with a daughter of your father and his wife. She is your own sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your father’s sister. She is your paternal aunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your mother’s sister. She is your maternal aunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with the wife of your father’s brother. She, too, is your aunt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your daughter-in-law. She is your son’s wife. Never have sexual intercourse with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your sister-in-law. She is your brother’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with a woman and her daughter or a woman and her granddaughter. They are related. Doing this is perverted.
speaker: Narrator

text: While your wife is living, never marry her sister as a rival wife and have sexual intercourse with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never have sexual intercourse with a woman while she is unclean during her monthly period.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your neighbor’s wife and become unclean with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never give your children as sacrifices to the god Molech by burning them alive. If you do, you are dishonoring the name of your Elohim. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with a man as with a woman. It is disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with any animal and become unclean with it. A woman must never offer herself to an animal for sexual intercourse. It is unnatural.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Do not become unclean in any of these ways. By these practices all the nations which I am forcing out of your way have become unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land has become unclean. I will punish it for its sins. The land will vomit out those who live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live by my standards, and obey my rules. Neither you nor any foreigner should ever do any of these disgusting things.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of the land who were there before you did all these disgusting things. As a result, the land has become unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you make the land unclean, it will vomit you out as it has vomited out the people who were there before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever does any of these disgusting things must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: So you must follow my instructions. Don’t live by the standards of the people who lived there before you. What they do is disgusting. Never become unclean that way. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the whole congregation of Israel: Be holy because I, Yahweh your Elohim, am holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Respect your mother and father. Observe my days of worship. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t turn to worthless gods or cast metal idols. Never make any gods for yourselves. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you bring a fellowship offering to Yahweh, sacrifice it properly so that you will be accepted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat your sacrifice on the day you bring it and on the next day. On the third day burn whatever is left over.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you eat any of it on the third day, it is repulsive and will not be accepted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who eat it will be punished because they have dishonored what is holy to Yahweh. They must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you harvest the grain in your land, don’t harvest the grain in the corners of your fields or gather what is left after you’re finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t harvest your vineyard a second time or pick up fallen grapes. Leave them for poor people and foreigners. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never steal, lie, or deceive your neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never swear by my name in order to deceive anyone. This dishonors the name of your Elohim. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never oppress or rob your neighbor. Never keep the pay you owe a hired worker overnight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never curse deaf people or put anything in the way of blind people to make them stumble. Instead, fear your Elohim. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be corrupt when administering justice. Never give special favors to poor people, and never show preference to important people. Judge your neighbor fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never gossip. Never endanger your neighbor’s life. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never hate another Israelite. Be sure to correct your neighbor so that you will not be guilty of sinning along with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never get revenge. Never hold a grudge against any of your people. Instead, love your neighbor as you love yourself. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Obey my laws. Never crossbreed different kinds of animals. Never plant two kinds of crops in your field. Never wear clothes made from two kinds of material.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man has sexual intercourse with a female slave who is engaged to another man and if her freedom was never bought or given to her, they should not be put to death. He will only pay a fine because she is a slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must bring a ram for his guilt offering to Yahweh at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: In Yahweh’s presence the priest will use them to make peace with the Lord for this sin. The man will be forgiven for this sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you come into the land and plant all kinds of fruit trees, you must not eat the fruit for the first three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fourth year all the fruit will be a holy offering of praise to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifth year you may eat the fruit. Do this to make the trees produce more for you. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Never eat any meat with blood still in it.
“Never cast evil spells, and never consult fortunetellers.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never shave the hair on your foreheads, and never cut the edges of your beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never slash your body to mourn the dead, and never get a tattoo. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never dishonor your daughter by making her a prostitute, or the country will turn to prostitution and be filled with people who are perverted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Observe my days of worship and respect my holy tent. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t turn to psychics or mediums to get help. That will make you unclean. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Show respect to the elderly, and honor older people. In this way you show respect for your Elohim. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Never mistreat a foreigner living in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Foreigners living among you will be like your own people. Love them as you love yourself, because you were foreigners living in Egypt. I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t be corrupt when administering justice concerning length, weight, or measuring liquid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Use honest scales, honest weights, and honest measures. I am Yahweh your Elohim who brought you out of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Obey all my laws and all my rules, and live by them. I am Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If Israelites or foreigners living among you give one of their children as a sacrifice to the god Molech, they must be put to death. The common people must stone them to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will condemn them and exclude them from the people. They gave one of their children to Molech, made my holy tent unclean, and dishonored my holy name.
speaker: Narrator

text: If the common people ignore those who give their children to Molech and do not put them to death,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will condemn them and their families. I will exclude them from the people. I will exclude from the people everyone who chases after Molech as if he were a prostitute.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will condemn people who turn to mediums and psychics and chase after them as though they were prostitutes. I will exclude them from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Live holy lives. Be holy because I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obey my laws, and live by them. I am Yahweh who sets you apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever curses his father or mother must be put to death. He has cursed his father or mother and deserves to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man commits adultery with another man’s wife or with his neighbor’s wife, both he and the woman must be put to death for their adultery.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever has sexual intercourse with his father’s wife has violated his father’s marriage. Both he and his father’s wife must be put to death. They deserve to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has sexual intercourse with his daughter-in-law, both of them must be put to death. They have done a disgusting thing and deserve to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man has sexual intercourse with another man as with a woman, both men are doing something disgusting and must be put to death. They deserve to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man marries a woman and her mother, they have done a perverted thing. The man and the two women must be burned. Never do this perverted thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: A man who has sexual intercourse with an animal must be put to death. You must kill the animal, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a woman offers herself sexually to any animal, you must kill both the woman and the animal. They must be put to death. They deserve to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever takes his sister, his father’s daughter or his mother’s daughter, and has sexual intercourse does a shameful thing. They both must be publicly excluded from the people. He has had sexual intercourse with his sister and must be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man has sexual intercourse with a woman while she has her monthly period, both of them have had sexual intercourse in blood. They must be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never have sexual intercourse with your mother’s sister or your father’s sister. Whoever has sexual intercourse with a close relative must be punished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever has sexual intercourse with his uncle’s wife violates his uncle’s marriage. That man and woman are guilty of sin. They will die without children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever marries his brother’s wife violates his brother’s marriage and does an unclean thing. That man and woman will have no children.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you carefully obey all my laws and my rules, the land I am bringing you to live in will not vomit you out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never follow the practices of the people I am forcing out of your way. I cannot stand them because they did all these things.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have told you that you will take their land. I will give it to you as your own. It is a land flowing with milk and honey. I am Yahweh your Elohim who separated you from other people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Separate clean and unclean animals and birds. Never become disgusting by eating any animal or bird or anything that crawls on the ground. I have separated you from every unclean thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be my holy people because I, Yahweh, am holy. I have separated you from other people to be my very own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every man or woman who is a medium or a psychic must be put to death. They must be stoned to death because they deserve to die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses, “Tell the priests, Aaron’s sons: None of you should become unclean by touching one of your relatives who has died.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, you are allowed to become unclean when one of your nearest relatives dies. These relatives include your mother, father, son, daughter, or brother,
speaker: Narrator

text: and especially an unmarried virgin sister who is still close to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the head of your people, you should never become unclean. That would make you unholy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You should never mourn by shaving bald spots on your heads, shaving the edges of your beards, or slashing your bodies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Be Elohim’s holy men, and don’t dishonor the name of your Elohim. Be holy because you bring sacrifices by fire to Yahweh. It is the food of your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: You should never marry prostitutes, those who have lost their virginity, or divorced women because a priest is Elohim’s holy man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be holy because you offer the food of your Elohim. Be holy because I, Yahweh, am holy. I set you apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a priest’s daughter dishonors herself by becoming a prostitute, she dishonors her father. She must be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The priest who is anointed with oil and wears the chief priest’s clothes is chief over his brothers. He must never mourn by leaving his hair uncombed or by tearing his clothes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must never go near any dead bodies or become unclean, even for his father or mother.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not leave the holy tent of his Elohim. If he does, he will be dishonoring it, because he is dedicated with the anointing oil of his Elohim. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The anointed priest must marry a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must never marry a widow, a divorced woman, a woman who has lost her virginity, or a prostitute. He may only marry a virgin from his own people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must not dishonor his children among his people because I, Yahweh, set him apart as holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron: If any of your descendants (now or in future generations) has a physical defect, he must never bring food to offer to Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, no one who has a physical defect may ever come near the altar. That means anyone who is blind or lame, who has a disfigured face, a deformity,
speaker: Narrator

text: or a crippled hand or foot,
speaker: Narrator

text: who is a hunchback or dwarf, who has defective sight, skin diseases, or crushed testicles.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a descendant of the priest Aaron has a physical defect, he must never bring sacrifices by fire to Yahweh. He has a defect. He must never bring food to offer to Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He may eat the food of his Elohim—what is holy and what is very holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, he must never come up to the canopy or to the altar, since he has a physical defect. He must never dishonor the holy places because I, Yahweh, set them apart as holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron and his sons that they must respect the holy offerings which the Israelites set apart for me. In this way they will not dishonor my holy name. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell them: In future generations if any of your descendants, while unclean, comes near the holy offerings the Israelites set apart for Yahweh, that person must be excluded from my presence. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “No descendant of Aaron who has a skin disease or a discharge may eat any of the holy offerings until he is clean. Any person who has an emission of semen or touches a dead body,
speaker: Narrator

text: an unclean swarming creature or an unclean person
speaker: Narrator

text: will be unclean until evening. He must not eat any of the holy offerings unless he has washed himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the sun has set, he will be clean. Then he may eat the holy offerings because they are his food.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must never eat the meat of an animal that dies naturally or is killed by wild animals. It will make him unclean. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests must do what I order, or their sin will bring them death because they dishonored a holy offering. I am Yahweh, who sets them apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Laypeople must never eat any holy offering, even if they are visiting a priest or are working for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if a priest buys a slave, the slave and anyone born in his household may eat the priest’s food.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if a priest’s daughter marries a layman, she must never eat the food taken from the holy contributions.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a priest’s daughter is widowed or divorced, doesn’t have any children, and comes back to live in her father’s home, she may eat her father’s food. But a layperson must never eat it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Those who eat a holy offering by mistake must give another holy offering to the priest and add one-fifth more to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Priests must not dishonor the holy offerings that the Israelites contribute to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must make those people pay the penalty for their guilt because they have eaten the priests’ holy offerings. I am Yahweh, who sets them apart as holy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Aaron, his sons, and all the Israelites: Israelites or foreigners may bring burnt offerings to Yahweh for anything they vowed or as freewill offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The offering must be a male that has no defects from your cattle, sheep, or goats in order to be accepted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never bring any animal with a physical defect, because it will not be accepted on your behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text: A person may bring Yahweh a fellowship offering to fulfill a vow or for a freewill offering. Whether it is from the cattle, sheep, or goats, it must be an animal that has no defects in order to be accepted. It must never be an animal that has defects.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never bring Yahweh an animal that is blind, has broken bones, cuts, warts, scabs, or ringworm. Never give Yahweh any of these in a sacrifice by fire on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may use a bull or a sheep with a deformity or one that is stunted in growth as a freewill offering. However, it will not be accepted for a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never bring Yahweh an animal that has bruised, crushed, torn out, or cut out testicles. Never do any of these things to an animal in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never bring any kind of castrated animal received from a foreigner as a food offering for your Elohim. A castrated animal will not be accepted on your behalf because castration is a physical defect.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “When a calf, a lamb, or a goat is born, it must stay with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day on it may be accepted as a sacrifice by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never slaughter a cow or a sheep and its young the same day.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you sacrifice a thank offering to Yahweh, do it in the proper way.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eat it the same day. Never leave any of it until morning. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Carefully obey my commands. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never dishonor my holy name. I will show my holiness among the Israelites. I am Yahweh, who sets you apart as holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brought you out of Egypt to be your Elohim. I am Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: These are the appointed festivals with Yahweh, which you must announce as holy assemblies.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may work for six days. But the seventh day is a day of worship, a day when you don’t work, a holy assembly. Don’t do any work. It is Yahweh’s day of worship wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The following are Yahweh’s appointed festivals with holy assemblies, which you must announce at their appointed times.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The fourteenth day of the first month, in the evening, is Yahweh’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifteenth day of this same month is Yahweh’s Festival of Unleavened Bread. For seven days you must eat unleavened bread.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day there will be a holy assembly. Don’t do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring Yahweh a sacrifice by fire for seven days. On the seventh day there will be a holy assembly. Don’t do any regular work.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: When you come to the land I am going to give you and you harvest grain, bring the priest a bundle of the first grain you harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will present it to Yahweh so that you will be accepted. He will present it on the day after Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the day you present the bundle, you must sacrifice a one-year-old male lamb that has no defects as a burnt offering to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring a grain offering of four quarts of flour mixed with olive oil with it. This will be a sacrifice by fire made to Yahweh, a soothing aroma. Use one quart of wine for the wine offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t eat bread, roasted grain, or fresh grain until this same day, when you bring the offering to your Elohim. It is a permanent law for generations to come wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count seven full weeks from the day after Passover (the day you bring the bundle of grain as an offering presented to the Lord)
speaker: Narrator

text: until the day after the seventh week. This is a total of fifty days. Then bring a new grain offering to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring two loaves of bread from your homes to present to the Lord. Bake them with four quarts of flour. They are the first harvested grain for Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the bread bring seven one-year-old lambs that have no defects, one bull, and two rams. They will be a burnt offering to Yahweh. With these offerings also bring grain and wine offerings. They will be a sacrifice by fire, a soothing aroma to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also sacrifice one male goat as an offering for sin and two one-year-old lambs as a fellowship offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must present them along with the bread of the first harvested grain as an offering to Yahweh. All this, along with the two lambs, will be holy and will belong to Yahweh’s priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make an announcement that there will be a holy assembly on that same day. Don’t do any regular work. It is a permanent law for generations to come wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When you harvest the grain in your land, don’t harvest the grain in the corners of your fields or gather what is left after you’re finished. Leave it for poor people and foreigners. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: On the first day of the seventh month hold a worship festival. It will be a memorial day, a holy assembly announced by the blowing of rams’ horns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t do any regular work. Bring a sacrifice by fire to Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “In addition, the tenth day of this seventh month is a special day for the payment for sins. There will be a holy assembly. Humble yourselves, and bring Yahweh a sacrifice by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t do any work that day. It is a special day for the payment for sins. It is a time when you make peace with Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who do not humble themselves on that day will be excluded from the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will kill those who do any work on that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t do any work. It is a permanent law for generations to come wherever you live.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a day of worship, a day when you don’t work. Humble yourselves starting on the evening of the ninth day of the month. From that evening to the next, observe the day of worship.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: The fifteenth day of this seventh month is the Festival of Booths to Yahweh. It will last seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day there will be a holy assembly. Don’t do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: For seven consecutive days bring a sacrifice by fire to Yahweh. On the eighth day there will be a holy assembly. Bring Yahweh a sacrifice by fire. This is the last festival of the year. Don’t do any regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “These are Yahweh’s appointed festivals. Announce them as holy assemblies for bringing sacrifices by fire to Yahweh. Bring burnt offerings, grain offerings, other sacrifices, and wine offerings—each one on its special day.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is in addition to Yahweh’s days of worship, your gifts, all your vows, and your freewill offerings to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have gathered what the land produces, celebrate Yahweh’s festival for seven days. The first and the eighth days will be worship festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day take the best fruits, palm branches, the branches of leafy trees and poplars, and celebrate in the presence of Yahweh your Elohim for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is Yahweh’s festival. Celebrate it for seven days each year. This is a permanent law for generations to come. Celebrate this festival in the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Live in booths for seven days. Everyone born in Israel must live in booths
speaker: Narrator

text: so that generations to come may learn how I made the people of Israel live in booths when I brought them out of Egypt. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses told the Israelites about Yahweh’s appointed festivals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command the Israelites to bring you pure, virgin olive oil for the lamp stand so that the lamps won’t go out.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the tent of meeting, outside the canopy where the words of my promise are, Aaron must keep the lamps lit in Yahweh’s presence from evening until morning. It is a permanent law for generations to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aaron must keep the lamps on the pure gold lamp stand lit in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also take flour and bake twelve rings of bread. Each ring will contain four quarts of flour.
speaker: Narrator

text: Put them in two stacks of six each on the gold table in Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lay pure incense on top of each stack. The incense on the bread will be a reminder, an offering by fire to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day of worship a priest must arrange the bread in Yahweh’s presence. It is a continual reminder of my promise to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bread will belong to Aaron and his sons. They will eat it in a holy place. It is very holy, set apart from Yahweh’s offering by fire. This is a permanent law.”
speaker: Narrator

text: A man, whose mother was Shelomith (daughter of Dibri, from the tribe of Dan in Israel) and whose father was from Egypt, got into a quarrel with an Israelite in the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelite woman’s son began cursing Ha-shem and treating it with contempt. So they brought him to Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept him in custody until Yahweh told them what to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “The man who cursed my name must be taken outside the camp. All who heard him curse my name must lay their hands on his head. Then the whole congregation must stone him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also tell the Israelites: Those who treat their Elohim with contempt will be punished for their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: But those who curse Yahweh’s name must be put to death. The whole congregation must stone them to death. It makes no difference whether they are Israelites or foreigners. Whoever curses Ha-shem must die.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whoever kills another person must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever kills an animal must replace it, life for life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever injures a neighbor must receive the same injury in return—
speaker: Narrator

text: a broken bone for a broken bone, an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth. Whoever injures another person must receive the same injury in return.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever kills an animal must replace it. Whoever kills a person must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: The same rule applies to every one of you. It makes no difference whether you are a foreigner or an Israelite, because I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses spoke to the people of Israel. So the man who had cursed Yahweh’s name was taken outside the camp. There they stoned him to death. The Israelites did as Yahweh commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: When you come into the land I’m giving you, the land will celebrate a year to honor Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, for six years you may plant crops in your fields, prune your vineyards, and gather what they produce.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the seventh year will be a festival year for the land. It will be a year to honor Yahweh. Don’t plant crops in your fields or prune your vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t harvest what grows by itself or harvest grapes from your vines. That year will be a festival for the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever the land produces during that year is for all of you to eat—for you, your male and female slaves, your hired workers, foreigners among you,
speaker: Narrator

text: your animals and the wild animals in your land. Everything the land produces will be yours to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Count seven of these years seven times for a total of 49 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the tenth day of the seventh month, the special day for the payment for sin, sound rams’ horns throughout the country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Set apart the fiftieth year as holy, and proclaim liberty to everyone living in the land. This is your jubilee year. Every slave will be freed in order to return to his property and to his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: That fiftieth year will be your jubilee year. Don’t plant or harvest what grows by itself or pick grapes from the vines in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The jubilee year will be holy to you. You will eat what the field itself produces.
speaker: Narrator

text: “In this jubilee year every slave will be freed in order to return to his property.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you sell anything to your neighbor or buy anything from him, don’t take advantage of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you buy property from your neighbor, take into account the number of years since the jubilee. Your neighbor must sell it to you taking into account the number of crops until the next jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are still many years until the jubilee, you will pay more for it. If there are only a few years until the jubilee, you will pay less for it because he is selling you only the number of crops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never take advantage of each other. Fear your Elohim, because I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Obey my laws, and carefully follow my rules. Then you will live securely in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land will give you its products, and you will eat all you want and live there securely.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may ask, ‘What will we eat in the seventh year if we do not plant or bring in our crops?’
speaker: Narrator

text: I will give you my blessing in the sixth year so that the land will produce enough for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will plant again in the eighth year but live on what the land already produced. You will eat it, even in the ninth year, until the land produces more.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Land must never be sold permanently, because the land is mine. To me you are strangers without permanent homes.
speaker: Narrator

text: People must always have the right to buy their property back.
speaker: Narrator

text: If your brother becomes poor and sells some of his property, then the one who can assume responsibility, his nearest relative, must buy back what he sold.
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man doesn’t have anyone to buy it back for him, but if he prospers and earns enough to buy it back himself,
speaker: Narrator

text: he must count the years from its sale. Then he will pay what is left to the man to whom he sold it, and it will be his property again.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, if he cannot earn enough to buy it back, what he sold stays in the hands of the buyer until the year of jubilee. In the jubilee it will be released, and he will own it again.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If anyone sells a home in a walled city, for one year after selling it he has the right to buy it back. He may buy it back only within that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he does not buy it back during that year, the house in the city belongs to the buyer for generations to come. It will not be released in the jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, houses in villages without walls are regarded as belonging to the fields of the land. They can be bought back. They will be released in the jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Levites always have the right to buy back their property in the cities they own.
speaker: Narrator

text: If any Levite buys back a house, in the jubilee the purchased house in the city will be released, because the houses in the Levite cities are their property among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a field that belongs to their cities must not be sold, because it is their permanent property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If an Israelite becomes poor and cannot support himself, help him. He must live with you as a stranger without a permanent home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t collect interest or make any profit from him. Fear your Elohim by respecting other Israelites’ lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Never collect any kind of interest on your money or on the food you give them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am Yahweh your Elohim, who brought you out of Egypt to give you Canaan and to be your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If an Israelite becomes poor and sells himself to you, don’t work him like a slave.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be like a hired worker or a visitor to you. He may work with you until the year of jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will release him and his children to go back to their family and the property of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are my servants. I brought them out of Egypt. They must never be sold as slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not treat them harshly. Fear your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You may have male and female slaves, but buy them from the nations around you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may also buy them from the foreigners living among you and from their families born in your country. They will be your property.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may acquire them for yourselves and for your descendants as permanent property. You may work them as slaves. However, do not treat the Israelites harshly. They are your relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Someone who is a foreigner without a permanent home among you may become rich, and your relative living with him may be poor. The poor Israelite may sell himself to that foreigner or a member of his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: After he has sold himself, he has the right to be bought back. One of his brothers may buy him back.
speaker: Narrator

text: His uncle, his cousin, or some other relative could also buy him back. If he becomes rich, he could buy his own freedom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he and his buyer must take into account the number of years from the year he was bought until the year of jubilee. His sale price will be adjusted based on the number of years he was with his buyer, like the wages of a hired worker.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are many years left, he must refund from his purchase price an amount equal to those years.
speaker: Narrator

text: If there are only a few years left until the year of jubilee, he must take them into account. He must refund from his purchase price an amount equal to those years.
speaker: Narrator

text: During those years he should serve his buyer as a hired worker. His buyer should not treat him harshly.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he cannot buy his freedom in these ways, he and his children will be released in the year of jubilee.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Israelites belong to me as servants. They are my servants. I brought them out of Egypt. I am Yahweh your Elohim.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued, “Never make worthless idols or set up a carved statue or a sacred stone for yourselves. Never cut figures in stone to worship them in your country, because I am Yahweh your Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Observe my days of worship and respect my holy tent. I am Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is what I will do if you will live by my laws and carefully obey my commands:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will give you rain at the right time. The land will produce its crops, and the trees in the field will produce their fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Threshing time will last until grape gathering, and grape gathering will last until planting. You will eat all you want and live securely in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will bring peace to your land. You will lie down with no one to scare you. I will remove dangerous animals, and there will be no war in your land.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will chase your enemies, and you will defeat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five of you will chase a hundred of them, and a hundred of you will chase ten thousand of them. You will defeat your enemies,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will be pleased with you. Your families will be large, and I will keep my promise to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will clear out old food supplies to make room for new ones.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will put my tent among you, and I will never look at you with disgust.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I will live among you and be your Elohim, and you will be my people.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am Yahweh your Elohim. I brought you out of Egypt so that you are no longer slaves of the Egyptians. I have broken their power over you and made you live as a free people.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you will not listen to me and obey all these commands,
speaker: Narrator

text: if you reject my laws and look at my rules with disgust, if you reject my promise by disobeying my commands,
speaker: Narrator

text: then this is what I will do to you: I will terrorize you with disease and fever. You will suffer from eye problems and depression. You will plant your crops and get nothing because your enemies will eat them.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will condemn you so that you will go down in defeat in front of your enemies. Those who hate you will be your rulers. You will run away even when no one is chasing you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you still will not listen to me, I will discipline you seven times for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will crush your arrogance. You will have no rain, and your land will be as hard as cement.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will work hard for nothing because your land will produce no crops and the trees will produce no fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you resist and don’t listen to me, I will increase the punishment for your sins seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send wild animals among you. They will rob you of your children, destroy your cattle, and make you so few that your roads will be deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If this discipline does not help and you still resist,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I, too, will resist you. I will punish you seven times for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will bring war on you to get revenge for my promise that you rejected. When you gather in your cities, I will send plagues on you and you will fall under the control of your enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy your food supply. Ten women will need only one oven to prepare your food. You will eat and go away hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If in spite of this you do not listen to me and still resist me,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will fiercely resist you. I will discipline you seven times for your sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will eat the bodies of your sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will destroy your worship sites, cut down your incense altars, and pile your dead bodies on top of your dead idols. I will look at you with disgust.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your cities deserted and ruin your sacred places. I will no longer accept the soothing aroma from your sacrifices.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your land so deserted that your enemies will be shocked as they settle in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will scatter you among the nations. War will follow you. Your country will be in ruins. Your cities will be deserted.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then the land will enjoy its time to honor the Lord while it lies deserted and you are in your enemies’ land. Then the land will joyfully celebrate its time to honor the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the days it lies deserted, it will celebrate the time to honor the Lord it never celebrated while you lived there.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will fill with despair those who are left in the land of their enemies. The sound of a windblown leaf will make them run. They will run away and fall, but no one will be chasing them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will stumble over each other, but no one will be after them. They will not be able to stand up to their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will be destroyed among the nations. The land of their enemies will devour them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are left will waste away in the lands of their enemies because of their sins and the sins of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But if they confess their sins and the sins of their ancestors—the treacherous things they did to oppose me—
speaker: Narrator

text: I will oppose them and bring them into the lands of their enemies. Then, if they humble their uncircumcised hearts and accept their guilt,
speaker: Narrator

text: I will remember my promise to Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham. I will also remember the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land, abandoned by them, will enjoy its time to honor the Lord while it lies deserted without them. They must accept their guilt because they rejected my rules and looked at my laws with disgust.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them or look at them with disgust. I will not reject or cancel my promise to them, because I am Yahweh their Elohim.
speaker: Narrator

text: But for their sake, I will remember the promise to their ancestors. I brought them out of Egypt to be their Elohim while nations looked on. I am Yahweh.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the laws, rules, and instructions that Yahweh gave to the Israelites through Moses on Mount Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yahweh spoke to Moses,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the Israelites: If any of you makes a special vow to give a person to Yahweh, you may give money instead of the person.
speaker: Narrator

text: The amount you must give for a man from 20 to 60 years old is 20 ounces of silver. Use the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is a woman, give 12 ounces.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a boy from 5 to 20 years old, give 8 ounces and for a girl give 4 ounces.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a boy from one month to five years old, give 2 ounces of silver and for a girl give about one ounce.
speaker: Narrator

text: For a man 60 years or over, give 6 ounces and for a woman give 4 ounces.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the person who is too poor to pay the required amount must stand in front of the priest. The priest will determine the amount based on what the person can afford.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the vow is to give the kind of animal that people offer to Yahweh, it will be considered holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Don’t exchange or substitute animals, a good one for a bad one or a bad one for a good one. If you do exchange one animal for another, then both animals will be holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: If it is an unclean animal that cannot be brought to Yahweh as an offering, bring it in front of the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest will determine what its value is. The value will be whatever the priest decides.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you want to buy it back, you must pay its full value plus one-fifth more.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you give your house to Yahweh as something holy, the priest will determine what its value is. The value will be whatever the priest decides.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you want to buy it back, you must pay its full value plus one-fifth more.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a person gives part of a field to Yahweh as something holy, its value will be based on the seed planted on it. Ground planted with 2 quarts of barley will be worth 20 ounces of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you give your field in the jubilee year, it will have its full value.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you give the field after the jubilee year, the priest will estimate its value based on the number of years left until the next jubilee year.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you want to buy it back, you must pay its full value plus one-fifth more.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you don’t buy it back and it is sold to someone else, you cannot buy it back.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the field is released in the jubilee year, it will be holy like a field claimed by Yahweh. It will become the property of the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may give a field you bought (not one that was a part of your family property) to Yahweh as something holy.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest must figure out the field’s value until the jubilee year. You will pay its value on that day as something holy, belonging to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the jubilee year the field will go back to the person from whom it was bought, to whom it belongs as family property.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All values will be set using the standard weight of the holy place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “A firstborn animal already belongs to Yahweh because it was born first. Therefore, it cannot be set apart as holy. Whether it is a bull or a sheep, it belongs to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if it is an unclean animal, it must be bought back. The payment will be its full value plus one-fifth more. If it is not bought back, it must be sold at the value given it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “However, everything dedicated to Yahweh for destruction—a person, an animal, or a field that belongs to you—must not be sold or bought back. Everything dedicated in that way is very holy. It belongs to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: People dedicated this way cannot be bought back. They must be put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: “One-tenth of what comes from the land, whether grain or fruit, is holy and belongs to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you buy back any part of it, you must add one-fifth more to it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every tenth head of cattle or sheep that you counted is holy and belongs to Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must not look to see if it is good or bad or exchange it. But if you do exchange it, both the first animal and its substitute will be holy. They cannot be bought back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the commands Yahweh gave Moses on Mount Sinai for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator
